natural problem: Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices.
natural solution: The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes club_members president_vice_president :: nat
assumes h0 : "club_members = 20"
and h1 : "10 boys and 10 girls"
and h2 : "no one can hold both offices"
and h3 : "president and vice-president must be of the same gender"
shows  "president_vice_president = 180"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes club_members president_vice_president :: nat
assumes h0 : "club_members = 20"
and h1 : "10 boys and 10 girls"
and h2 : "no one can hold both offices"
and h3 : "president and vice-president must be of the same gender"
shows  "president_vice_president = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a club, there are 20 members, with an equal number of boys and girls (10 boys and 10 girls). The club needs to elect a president and a vice-president, but no one can hold both offices. Additionally, the president and vice-president must be of the same gender. How many different ways can the president and vice-president be chosen? The final answer is 180.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls total_members ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_members = boys + girls"
and h3 : "ways = (boys * (boys - 1)) + (girls * (girls - 1))"
shows  "ways = 180"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls total_members ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_members = boys + girls"
and h3 : "ways = (boys * (boys - 1)) + (girls * (girls - 1))"
shows  "ways = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: There are 10 boys and 10 girls in a group. Calculate the number of ways to choose a pair of members, either both boys, both girls, or one boy and one girl. The final answer is 180.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members boys girls :: nat
and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "choose boys 2 + choose girls 2 = 180"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes members boys girls :: nat
and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "choose = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "choose boys 2 + choose girls 2 = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a group of 20 members, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. How many ways are there to choose a pair of either 2 boys or 2 girls? The final answer is 180 ways.

and h3 : "ways = boys * (boys - 1) + girls * (girls - 1)"
shows  "ways = 180"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls president vice_president :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "president + vice_president = 20"
and h3 : "president * vice_president = 180"
shows  "\<exists>ways. ways = 180"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls president vice_president :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "president + vice_president = 20"
and h3 : "president * vice_president = 180"
shows  "\<exists>ways. ways = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: There are 10 boys and 10 girls in a class. The sum of the number of boys who can be president and the number of girls who can be vice-president is 20. The product of the number of boys who can be president and the number of girls who can be vice-president is 180. How many ways can a president and vice-president be chosen? The final answer is 180.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members boys girls :: nat and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "choose 2 = 10 * 9"
shows  "choose 2 * 2 = 180"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes members boys girls :: nat and choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "choose 2 = 10 * 9"
shows  "choose 2 * 2 = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a group of 20 members, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. If you can choose 2 people from the group, and there are $\frac{10 \times 9}{2}$ ways to do this, find the total number of ways to choose 2 pairs of people. The final answer is 180.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls total_members :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n < total_members \<longrightarrow> (n choose 2) \<le> (total_members choose 2)"
shows  "(boys choose 2) + (girls choose 2) = 180"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls total_members :: nat
assumes h0 : "total_members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> n. n < total_members \<longrightarrow> (n choose 2) \<le> (total_members choose 2)"
shows  "(boys choose 2) + (girls choose 2) = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a group of 20 members, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. How many ways are there to form a pair of members such that either both are boys or both are girls? The final answer is 180.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes members boys girls ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> president vice_president. president \<noteq> vice_president \<and> (president \<in> boys \<and> vice_president \<in> boys \<or> president \<in> girls \<and> vice_president \<in> girls) \<longrightarrow> ways \<ge> 1"
shows  "ways = 180"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes members boys girls ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "members = 20"
and h1 : "boys = 10"
and h2 : "girls = 10"
and h3 : "\<forall> president vice_president. president \<noteq> vice_president \<and> (president \<in> boys \<and> vice_president \<in> boys \<or> president \<in> girls \<and> vice_president \<in> girls) \<longrightarrow> ways \<ge> 1"
shows  "ways = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a club of 20 members, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. How many ways can a president and vice-president be chosen such that both are boys or both are girls, and the president and vice-president are different people? The final answer is 180 ways.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n_boys n_girls :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_boys = 10"
and h1 : "n_girls = 10"
shows  "card {((b1, b2), (g1, g2)). b1 \<in> {1..n_boys}, b2 \<in> ({1..n_boys} - {b1}), g1 \<in> {1..n_girls}, g2 \<in> ({1..n_girls} - {g1})} = 180"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Our club has 20 members, 10 boys and 10 girls.  In how many ways can we choose a president and a vice-president if they must be of the same gender?  Assume no one can hold both offices. The final Answer is 180
 ### Proof
 The president can be any one of the 20 members, and the vice-president can be any one of the 9 remaining members of the same sex. The answer is $20\times 9=\boxed{180}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n_boys n_girls :: nat
assumes h0 : "n_boys = 10"
and h1 : "n_girls = 10"
shows  "card {((b1, b2), (g1, g2)). b1 \<in> {1..n_boys}, b2 \<in> ({1..n_boys} - {b1}), g1 \<in> {1..n_girls}, g2 \<in> ({1..n_girls} - {g1})} = 180"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a group, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. How many different pairs of two boys and two girls can be formed, with the restriction that the same person cannot be in the pair twice? The final answer is 180.
